title: Identifying The Right ‘Why’ For AI
description: Those who define their "why" with precision unlock efficiency and go on to create transformative, durable value.
content:
Agur Jõgi, CTO of Pipedrive and expert in scaling technology and organizations. Experienced as an innovator, founder and C-level manager.

Here’s the spoiler up front: Your AI strategy is only as strong as your "why."

AI is no longer a technical novelty; it’s an explicit executive mandate from many business leaders that has resulted in recent notable headlines. Particularly in the SaaS sector, where differentiation is hard-won and retention is king, leaders are heavily investing in AI to reshape their products, platforms and internal corporate operations. It has the hallmarks of a hype bubble—though that’s not saying that AI benefits are all hot air. Far from it.

The core question should be "Why are you deploying AI in the first place?" Does the reason make strategic sense? It’s easy to be seduced by the excitement of emerging capabilities—never mind the sense of urgency as peers and seemingly everyone else are making their big bets. While early industry missteps might be a result of overenthusiastic decision making, those that don’t wise up and set a clear vision and roadmap risk spiraling, wasting time, money and goodwill.

If enterprises are to secure real value from their AI investments, then all steps need to be taken with careful intention and an eye on possible second-order effects and perceptions. Companies rushing to deploy without clarity can risk misalignment, wasted investment and erosion of customer (and employee) trust. Those who define their "why" with precision unlock efficiency and go on to create transformative, durable value.

The technology industry has no shortage of new AI-powered features. Some have raised immediate questions, like AI assistants in social media sharing chats to the social feed. Some show immediate and quantifiable value, like automatically suggesting follow-up actions after a recorded meeting. There’s a tension in the rush to show value, with some features being more ornamental than essential. The line between innovation and intrusion can be thin without clear intentionality and an articulated strategy.

That "ornamentality," when AI is used reactively and bolted onto software products in response to perceived market pressure or investor expectations, can quickly result in increased user friction, features that sound intelligent but feel irrelevant and operational drag from maintaining underused systems.

Tech leaders must resist a knee-jerk impulse. Every AI investment should begin not with what’s possible, but with what’s strategic.

The Strategic ‘Why’—Anchoring AI In Value Drivers

In SaaS, AI has the potential to impact three core value drivers. These are customer retention, operational scalability and product stickiness. Ask yourself: Where do customers most struggle in their journey? What decisions are made repeatedly that could be improved or automated? How can AI extend the value of the core product without diluting its usability?

Here are some examples of high-leverage "whys":
• Customer success: AI-powered onboarding guidance tailored to industry use case, maturity or other important parameters.
• Support operations: Predictive classification and resolution of support tickets, reducing average time to resolution.
• Product usage: Intelligent surfacing of features based on behavior, improving feature adoption and upsell.

These aren’t ornamental features—they are force multipliers. But only if the problem and opportunity are well understood and then carefully applied.

While the field hasn’t been active for long, those looking for AI missteps can spy some patterns:
• Automating before understanding: Replacing workflows without modeling the nuance behind them.
• Forgetting fallback paths: Relying on AI systems without any human override points leads to avoidable failure points.

Tech companies, particularly SaaS companies, operate in dynamic, high-stakes environments. Trust, clarity and control aren’t just nice-to-haves; they are product requirements. Any AI deployment that weakens those will backfire and damage the brand offering.

Getting It Right

Treat AI as a portfolio investment. Not all initiatives carry the same risk or ROI. Leaders must balance issues such as efficiency bets (like internal automations offering a clear cost saving), product bets (features that deepen user engagement or enable premium pricing) and exploration bets (new paradigms and genuine whitespace innovation). Each should have a business case, success metrics and review cadence.

Validate these bets with real (not vanity) metrics, like pre-agreed user and market signals. Pilot projects internally or with friendly early adopters. Gather usage data, not just sentiment. Aim to learn fast, iterate decisively and avoid scaling mistakes and distractions.

Think and act cross-functionally. AI strategy must involve product, engineering, design, legal and data science, all from day one. Establish shared principles around bias mitigation, data governance and explainability. Yes, it’s more work, but AI features can become white elephants, red herrings and black marks. Use diverse brainpower to solve for problems no one person or team can see alone.

Put your own lifejacket on first. Internal use cases are golden paths to learning as well as making immediate bottom-line gains.

For example, documentation summarization for onboarding new engineers, sales enablement tools that auto-tailor pitches based on CRM signals or auto-tagging of product feedback to inform roadmap prioritization. Internal wins are easier to implement; they build organizational muscle and intelligence. That all supports a stronger external launch.

Tech companies sit at an intersection of massive data flows, evolving customer expectations and fierce competition. AI offers unprecedented tools, but without that strategic "why," those tools risk becoming distractions.

The leaders who define their AI strategy around real user pain, product leverage and organizational readiness will be the ones who win. Not just by shipping AI features, but by building smarter, more adaptive companies. Every big technological shift has been successful in its implementation only with the right practices and culture as well. When starting with strategy, it’s so much easier to ensure every piece of the puzzle falls into place.

The author suggests that while AI-powered features are often more ornamental than essential, some features can lead to increased user friction, features that sound intelligent but feel irrelevant and operational drag from maintaining underused systems. The article also suggests that companies should prioritise customer retention, operational scalability and product stickiness for AI-based solutions.

Forbes Technology Council Is A Vetted Professional Organization For Senior-Level Technology Executives
Who is Forbes Technology Council for?
Members of Forbes Technology Council are respected technology leaders selected for the Council for their depth and diversity of experience.
To qualify, you must be a senior-level technology executive and your company must generate at least $1,000,000 USD in annual revenue, or have received $1,000,000 USD in funding to date.
Eligible applicants are vetted by our selection committee, and if approved, are invited to select and purchase a membership package.
Examples of Forbes Technology Council members include founders, partners, and CEOs of technology companies, C-level technology executives such as CTOs and CIOs, and VPs of technology teams.
Start Your Application
Why Join Forbes Technology Council
Be Recognized As An Expert
Our platform allows you to easily share your technology expertise through quick, concise quotes using our mobile app or web portal via Expert Panels. Members can select questions they have a unique perspective on and provide a response in under 400 characters. Then, the most apt responses are curated by our editorial team and distilled into a single piece.
Expert Panels are the ideal path to increasing your visibility while balancing a demanding schedule, and all include your name, company name, and link to your Executive Profile.
Publishing Bylined Articles on Forbes.com
Forbes Technology Council members can submit bylined articles to be published on Forbes.com, each piece is edited collaboratively with our team of expert editors to meet the publication’s guidelines. Articles are published on Forbes.com and syndicated across our social media channels, select pieces get extra promotion in our Tech Pulse newsletter.
Articles feature your headshot and bio. You’ll also receive an author page on Forbes.com which includes your headshot, name, short-form bio, and a link to your full Executive Profile.
Your Executive Profile on Forbes.com
Your Executive Profile on Forbes.com is optimized to be search-friendly, affirming your credibility as a technology leader. Profiles include your headshot, professional bio, company description, links to your social media and website, and all of the content you’ve been featured in on Forbes.com.
You’ll also receive an assortment of badging options for use on social media and business websites, highlighting your status as a Forbes Technology Council member.
Forbes Technology Council gives us credibility inside our industry and with customers. It helps distinguish us from the competition.
Carlos Melendez
COO and Co-Founder, Wovenware
Additional Benefits for Forbes Councils Members
Connect, Learn, and Grow With Your Peers
Through our member portal and mobile app, you’ll be able to connect with a network of like-minded, successful entrepreneurs. As a member, you’ll be able to message others directly, share insights, pose questions, and participate in council-wide and group conversations.
With exclusive access to other technology leaders, the opportunities for business development and strategic partnerships are plenty.
Our members are committed to a lifetime of learning and growth. We host regular virtual events, led by a broad range of experts on the topics most relevant to you and your work, providing you you the breadth of information required to address dynamic, real-time technology challenges.
Interactive Groups
Within our exclusive member app, you’ll be able to join and create Groups — where you can connect, ask and answer questions, and start conversations with members of similar interests and industries.
Member Badges
As a member, you’ll have access to Forbes Councils badges, email signatures, social graphics, and press release templates. We make it easy for you to share your affiliation with the Forbes community.
Virtual Events
Be inspired by experts at virtual live events and in interactive member-led Groups. Our private events are hosted by industry experts in a variety of fields to address today’s critical issues.
Mobile App
Stay updated on the go with the Forbes Councils mobile app available on iOS and Android making it easy to participate in Expert Panels and connect with other members.
EXEC Benefits Program
You’ll receive complimentary access to EXEC, a curated hotel, travel, lifestyle, and business benefits program designed to improve the lives of busy executives.
Private Business Coaching
Available for an additional cost, you can get matched with a certified coach, who will guide you and your company to reach your highest professional and business goals.
Dedicated Member Support Team
At the core of the Forbes Councils experience is our member support team. Our team is dedicated to helping you get the most of your membership and resources.
Complimentary Strategy Session
Qualified members receive access to a free 30-minute strategy session with a premium business coach to help you discover hidden profit drivers and hone your focus.
